details.title: Fundamentals of Chemistry Lab
details.prerequisite: Credit for or concurrent enrollment in CHEM 1311.
details.description: Illustrates and reinforces principles and concepts by use of qualitative and quantitative experiments, emphasizing interpretation and reporting of data and facility in handling scientific instruments.
details.note: Credit may not be applied toward a degree for both CHEM 1111 and CHEM 1105 or CHEM 1117.

details.title: Fundamentals of Chemistry
details.description: General principles, fundamental laws, atomic & molecular structure, states of matter, & elementary inorganic, nuclear & organic chemistry.
details.note: For science and engineering majors. May not be applied toward a degree until CHEM 1111 is successfully completed. Credit may not be applied to a degree for both CHEM 1311 and CHEM 1305 or CHEM 1372.

details.title: Introduction To Engineering
details.corequisite: Credit for or enrollment in MATH 2413.
details.description: Engineering undergraduate standing or permission of the Director of Undergraduate Programs in Engineering. Overview of engineering, information about various engineering disciplines, introductory problem-solving, engineering design, and engineering ethics.

details.title: First Year Writing I
details.prerequisite: A TSI placement score of at least 340, and an essay score of at least a 4 on the TSI Writing Assessment; or a placement score of less than 340, and an ABE Diagnostic level of at least 4, and an essay score of at least 5 on the TSI Writing Assessment; and a score ranging from 351 to 390 on the TSI Reading Assessment. Students may exempt the TSI by obtaining satisfactory scores on other accepted standardized tests. See http://www.uh.edu/ussc/tsi/ for details.
details.description: First Year Writing course focusing on developing writing skills.
details.note: Students who score below the minimum on the TSI must enroll concurrently in ENGL 1300 or, if slightly below the minimum writing score, in ENGL 1100. Students who score below the minimum on the TSI Reading Assessment must enroll concurrently in IRW 1300.

details.title: The United States to 1877*
details.description: The social, economic, and political history of the United States to 1877.

details.title: Calculus I
details.prerequisite: Credit for MATH 2312 with a grade of C- or higher, or a satisfactory score on a placement examination.
details.description: Calculus of rational functions, limits, derivatives, applications of the derivative, antiderivatives, the definite integral with applications, mean value theorem, fundamental theorem of calculus, and numerical integration.

details.title: Computing and Problem Solving for Engineers
details.prerequisite: ENGI 1100, MATH 2413 and CHEM 1311 OR PHYS 2325.
details.description: Engineering undergraduate standing or permission of the Director of Undergraduate Programs in Engineering. Introduction to computing; matrix arithmetic, programming constructs, algorithms and graphical visualization using MATLAB; problem solving applications in engineering analysis and design.

details.title: First Year Writing II
details.description: Detailed study of the principles of rhetoric as applied to analyzing and writing argumentative and persuasive essays; principles and methods of research, culminating in writing a substantial research paper.
details.note: Credit may not be received for both ENGL 1302 and ENGL 1310 or ENGL 1370.

details.title: The United States Since 1877
details.description: The social, economic, and political history of the United States since 1877.

details.title: Calculus II
details.prerequisite: Credit for MATH 2413 with a grade of C- or higher.
details.description: Calculus of transcendental functions: additional techniques and applications of integration, indeterminate forms, improper integrals, Taylor’s formula, and infinite series.

details.title: University Physics I (lecture)
details.corequisite: Credit for or concurrent enrollment in MATH 2414.
details.description: First semester of a two part calculus-based course covering mechanics of one- and two-dimensional motion, dynamics, energy, momentum, rotational dynamics and kinematics, statics, gravity, oscillations, waves and fluids.
details.note: Primarily for science and engineering majors. Credit may not be applied toward degree for both PHYS 2325 and PHYS 1301.

details.title: University Physics Laboratory I (lab)
details.corequisite: Credit for or concurrent enrollment in PHYS 2325.
details.description: Experiments in mechanics and wave motion.
details.note: Credit may not be applied toward a degree for both PHYS 2125 and PHYS 1101.

details.title: Circuit Analysis I
details.prerequisite: ENGI 1100, ENGI 1331, ENGL 1301 or ENGL 1309, ENGL 1302 or ENGL 1310, MATH 2413, MATH 2414, PHYS 2125, PHYS 2325.
details.corequisite: MATH 2415, MATH 3321, or MATH 2318 and MATH 3331, PHYS 2126, and PHYS 2326.
details.description: Analysis of resistive circuits, including node voltage and mesh current methods, and Thevenin and Norton equivalent circuits.

details.title: Calculus III
details.description: Calculus of functions of several variables: calculus of vector-valued functions, partial differentiation, multiple integrals.

details.title: Engineering Mathematics
details.description: First order ordinary differential equations and initial value problems; higher order differential equations; vector spaces, matrices, determinants, eigenvectors and eigenvalues; applications to systems of first order equations; Laplace transforms.
details.note: Students may not receive credit for both MATH 3321 and MATH 3331.

details.title: University Physics II (lecture)
details.corequisite: Credit for or concurrent enrollment in MATH 2415.
details.description: Second semester of a two part calculus-based course covering thermodynamics, electricity, magnetism, electromagnetic waves, optics, and modern physics.
details.note: Primarily for science and engineering majors. Credit may not be applied toward degree for both PHYS 2326 and PHYS 1302.

details.title: University Physics Laboratory II
details.corequisite: Credit for or concurrent enrollment in PHYS 2326.
details.description: Experiments in thermodynamics, electricity, magnetism, and optics.
details.note: Credit may not be applied toward a degree for both PHYS 2126 and PHYS 1102.

details.title: US and Texas Constitution and Politics
details.description: Introduction to the constitutions and politics of the United States and Texas, emphasizing constitutional structure, federalism, separation of powers, limited government, public opinion, elections, and civil liberties.

details.title: Technical Communications for Engineers
details.prerequisite: ENGI 1100, ENGL 1302, engineering undergraduate standing, and completion of one of the following courses: ECE 2201, CHEE 2331, ENGR 2301, INDE 2333, MECE 2336, PETR 2311 or permission of the Director of Undergraduate Programs.
details.description: Engineering communication skills: written proposals, specifications, progress reports, and technical reports; individual and group oral presentations; essays on engineering ethics, contemporary engineering issues and the impact of engineering decisions.

details.title: Circuit Analysis II
details.description: Analysis of electric circuits, including inductors, capacitors, and first order circuits; sinusoidal analysis.

details.title: Circuit Analysis Laboratory
details.prerequisite: Credit for or concurrent enrollment in ECE 2202.
details.description: Introduction to the electronics laboratory equipment. Introductory experiments in circuit analysis. Formal report writing. This laboratory course is a prerequisite for all other ECE laboratory courses.

details.title: Programming Applications in Electrical and Computer Engineering
details.prerequisite: MATH 3321 and credit for or concurrent enrollment in ECE 2201.
details.description: Procedural programming in C and C++, with applications in electrical and computer engineering.

details.title: Digital Logic Design
details.corequisite: Credit for or concurrent enrollment in ECE 2100.
details.description: Boolean algebra, combinational logic, sequential machine analysis and synthesis.

details.title: Introduction to Programming
details.prerequisite: A grade of C- or better in COSC 1336, and credit for or concurrent enrollment in MATH 2413.
details.description: Fundamental concepts of structured programming; procedures and elementary data structures with a focus on problem solving strategies and implementation; computer organization, structured procedural programming, C/C++ programming language, and algorithm design.

details.title: Electronics Laboratory
details.prerequisite: ECE 2100 and ENGI 2304 and credit for or concurrent enrollment in ECE 3355.
details.description: Laboratory projects concerning topics studied in electronics.

details.title: Electronics
details.corequisite: Credit for or concurrent enrollment in ECE 3337 and ECE 3155.
details.description: Signal and amplifier concepts; operational amplifiers; diodes and nonlinear circuits; bipolar junction transistors; biasing, small and large signal analysis; transistor amplifiers.

details.title: Microprocessor Systems
details.corequisite: Credit for or concurrent enrollment in ECE 2100.
details.description: Memory devices, microcomputer architecture, assembly language programming, I/O programming, I/O interface design, data communications, and data acquisition systems. Laboratory exercises in assembly language and C.

details.title: Signals and Systems Analysis
details.description: Time and frequency domain techniques for signals and systems analysis. Engineering applications of the convolution integral, Fourier series and transforms, and Laplace transforms.

details.title: Applied Electromagnetic Waves
details.corequisite: Credit for or concurrent enrollment in ECE 3337.
details.description: Maxwell’s equations in time and frequency domains, Poynting’s theorem, plane wave propagation, reflection and transmission in lossless and lossy media, transmission lines, waveguides, and antennas.

details.title: Discrete Mathematics
details.description: Topics selected from logic, set theory, combinatorics, and graph theory.

details.title: Introduction to Computer Architecture and Design
details.description: Computer organization, computer arithmetic, instruction sets, programming with MIPS assembly language, CPU design, pipelining, and memory hierarchy including caching and virtual memory.

details.title: Engineering Statistics I
details.description: Basic concepts of probability, discrete and continuous probability distributions, joint distributions for two random variables, covariance and correlation, descriptive statistics, and one-sample statistical inference (confidence interval and hypothesis testing) for engineering problems.

details.title: Principles of Microeconomics
details.prerequisite: MATH 1314 or equivalent or consent of instructor.
details.description: Individual consumer and firm behavior, supply and demand and the market determination of prices, production, and income. Includes government price ceilings, monopoly and antitrust, market failures, and environmental pollution.

details.title: Programming and Data Structures
details.prerequisite: A grade of C- or better in COSC 1437 and credit for or concurrent enrollment in MATH 2414.
details.description: Introduction to fundamental data structures: arrays, lists, stacks, queues, hash tables, trees; sorting and searching; graph algorithms; design, analysis, and comparison of algorithms. Correctness verification techniques such as assertions and invariants. Review program specification, unit testing, and debugging.

details.title: Electrical and Computer Engineering Design I
details.prerequisite: ECE 3155, ECE 3317, ECE 3340, ECE 3355, ECE 3436, INDE 2333, and a core approved economics elective.
details.description: Propose and begin team projects involving open-ended design problems supplied by industry and faculty. Professionalism, research methodologies, design tools, and technical communication.

details.title: Digital Electronics
details.description: Analysis of discrete and integrated digital electronic devices and components and their use in the design and implementation of digital circuits.

details.title: US Government: Congress, President, & Courts
details.description: Introduction to the institutions of government with an emphasis on the congress, the president, and the federal courts. (Introductory category.)

details.title: Electrical and Computer Engineering Design II
details.description: Complete, construct, demonstrate, and defend team projects begun in ECE 4335.

details.title: Fundamentals of Software Engineering
details.prerequisite: COSC majors and minors: A grade of C- or better in COSC 3320 and MATH 3336; CpE majors: A grade of C- or better in COSC 2320 and MATH 3336.
details.description: Introduction to the concepts of software engineering. Identification of problems related to the development of large software systems. Software project planning, requirements analysis, design, implementation, quality assurance and maintenance.

details.title: Art History II (15th Century to the Present)
details.description: Art and its relationship to society in and for which it was made from the Renaissance to the present.
details.note: Required for art and art history majors.

details.title: Introduction to Theatre
details.description: Students will gain a genuine appreciation for the art and craft of theatre by reading, attending, and writing critically about plays.

details.title: Listening to Classical Music
details.description: An introduction to the masterworks of Western music from Gregorian chant to the present.

details.title: Fundamentals of Theatre
details.prerequisite: Acceptance to the major by audition/portfolio review and consent of instructor.
details.description: Critical appreciation and practice of live theatre, emphasizing the synthesis of acting, direction, and design in the context of contemporary theatrical production.

arts.courseName: Ways of Seeing: Art and Our Visual World

details.title: Ways of Seeing: Art and Our Visual World
details.description: Examination of our visual world and the various ways in which that world has been analyzed and valued. May not be applied to a major or minor in art history or art.

details.title: Analog Electronics
details.description: Bipolar, MOS, and JFET transistors; multistage amplifier design; frequency response and feedback concepts; operational amplifiers; analysis and design using discrete and integrated devices.

details.title: Energy Conversion Laboratory
details.prerequisite: ECE 2100 and credit for or concurrent enrollment in ECE 4363.
details.description: Selected experiments in electromechanical energy conversion devices.

ece.courseName: Physical Principles of Solid State Devices

details.title: Physical Principles of Solid State Devices
details.prerequisite: ECE 3155, ECE 3355, and credit for or concurrent enrollment in ECE 4119.
details.description: Electronics, modern physics, and electromagnetism used to develop fundamental understanding of bipolar, Schottky, and MOS solid state device operation.

details.title: Introduction to Mechanical Design
details.corequisite: Credit for or concurrent enrollment in ENGI 2304 and in MECT 3341 or equivalent drafting experience.
details.description: Introduction to engineering design. Individual and group projects.

details.title: Materials Science
details.description: Properties of materials described by and related to materials structure. Emphasis on mechanical properties of materials.

details.title: Thermal Design
details.prerequisite: MECE 2334 and credit for or concurrent enrollment in MECE 4364.
details.description: Power and refrigeration cycles, mixture of ideal gases, basic combustion processes, equilibrium, thermodynamics of compressible flow, thermal system design.

details.title: Introduction to Fluid Mechanics
details.prerequisite: MECE 2334, MECE 3336, and credit for or concurrent enrollment in MATH 3363.
details.description: Fluid properties, control volume and differential balance equations, viscous and irrotational flows, dimensional analysis, laminar and turbulent flows.

details.title: Intro To Philosophy
details.description: Introduction to philosophy: issues such as the nature and extent of knowledge, the objectivity of scientific theories, the rationality of theistic belief, and human freedom.

details.title: Philosophy and the Arts
details.description: Introduction to philosophical topics in the visual and performing arts, including criticism, interpretation, moral issues, and cultural contexts.

details.title: Structures of Poetry
details.description: Comparison of novels representing various periods in Western cultures with emphasis on a broad historical perspective on the genre, as well as its special characteristics.

details.title: Introduction to Ethnic Studies
details.description: This course serves as an introduction to the study of race and ethnicity in the U.S. Through a combination of historical narratives, autobiography, fiction, and analytical essays, students will gain a glimpse into the spectrum of identities and issues inherent in American culture. Current issues and events will also be analyzed through the prism of race and ethnicity.
